question: What environmental problem is caused by gases released when gasoline is used?

content.source_1: Gasoline is a petroleum-derived liquid fuel; as a fossil fuel, it is commonly used to power internal combustion engine cars.
content.source_2: Burning fossil fuels in vehicle engines releases air pollutants—such as nitrogen oxides, carbon monoxide, volatile organic compounds, and particulate matter—that degrade air quality and contribute to smog.
content.source_3: In many cities worldwide, road-traffic exhaust is a leading contributor to urban air pollution and smog episodes.
content.source_4: Modern gasoline cars are equipped with three-way catalytic converters that substantially reduce tailpipe emissions of NOx, CO, and unburned hydrocarbons during normal operation.
content.source_5: Leaks from underground gasoline storage tanks and associated piping at service stations have caused widespread soil and groundwater contamination, with many tens of thousands of documented release sites.
content.source_6: Toxic constituents of gasoline, including benzene, can migrate with groundwater and contaminate drinking-water wells at very low concentrations.
